He yearned for what was lost, for the idealized past that perhaps never was, but in that yearning he created something new.

In his character of Frederic we see this clearest, like looking through dark water to stones beneath. Before he steps onto the stage we know him by the marks of chivalry upon his soul - a prince who has known suffering, who has walked through fire and shadow, believed dead at the hands of infidels in some far land. Here stands the knight of old tales, but twisted, exaggerated, excessive like all things gothic must be, as if viewed through a glass that magnifies and distorts until the familiar becomes strange and the strange becomes familiar.

They called it supply chain management and it was a thing born of necessity in the minds of men who sought to move goods across vast spaces from maker to buyer through the raw materials and the making and the moving and all manner of commerce between. A consultant named Oliver had given it this name in 1982 though the thing itself was ancient as trade itself. It was a process both simple and complex in its execution, like the weaving of a vast tapestry where each thread must find its place lest the whole thing come undone.

Six elements existed in this chain and they were like the bones of some great beast: production and supply and inventory and location and transportation and information. Each one vital as blood, each one carrying its own weight in the grand scheme of things.

Production stood first among these elements, a foundation stone upon which all else was built. In the way of all things it began with want, with need, with desire. The managers would study the market like seers reading entrails, trying to divine what the people would buy and what they would not. They would make their decisions based on these auguries, choosing what would be made and where it would be made and how many would be made. Each decision carried weight, each choice echoing down through the chain like thunder across empty plains.

He had seen this himself in the great retail houses of Walmart and Target, where every action was prescribed and every movement calculated, down to the very clothes the workers wore and the way the trucks were emptied of their goods. It was a machinery vast and precise, and like all machinery it could fail if not tended proper.

Then there was supply, that great decision of what would be done within the walls and what would be sent to others to do. They called it outsourcing when they sent the work away, seeking that thing they called velocity, though velocity was nothing more than the marriage of quality and flexibility with the eternal pursuit of lower costs. It was a dance of numbers and capabilities, of core competencies and strategic partnerships, all of it moving in a rhythm old as commerce itself.

They came in the dark Victorian age like wraiths or phantoms stalking the halls of literature. Books of the aristocracy and their ways. Books of parlors and teacups and proper manners laid bare upon the page in infinite detail as if God himself had ordained their cataloguing. But there were others. Different ones. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights stood apart from their kin like dark sheep in a pristine flock, carrying with them elements of mystery and the bizarre that no proper Victorian novel would dare embrace. These elements moved through the stories like smoke, seeping into the characters, making them more real somehow. More true.

"And now hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind." That's what they wrote of Oliver. He walked between Sikes and Crackit who were not there but were there all the same, their voices real as gunsmoke in his ears. The boy stumbled through this fever dream while shots rang out and lights blazed across his vision like St. Elmo's fire and all the while pain rode him like a demon, constant and merciless.

These fever dreams and nightmares served as windows into souls. In Oliver's case they laid bare the helplessness of a child cast adrift in a world of wolves. When the shooting came back to him in the twenty-eighth chapter it came like a visitation, like judgment. He was there again. The pistol. The flash. The darkness. Some unseen hand bearing him away while Sikes and Crackit argued in his head like specters at a hanging. The pain was everywhere and nowhere. It had become like breathing. Like existing. The boy was powerless in this world of men and monsters, his will counted for nothing, and old Fagin's poison had already begun to work its way into his blood, into his bones, into whatever remained of hope.

The day that wasnt a day passed and night came again. Long night. Short night. Silent as death and gone in an instant.

In them days I worked with the children after their schooling was done, them small faces bent over books and papers in the failing light. English and reading was what I knew best and that's what I done. There was this boy named Adrian, might've been nine or ten years old, struggling with his letters like a blind man counting coins. Something wasnt right with how he read. Some letters he knew true as sunrise but others might as well been hieroglyphs carved in stone by ancient peoples long dead.

The boy was Mexican sure enough but spoke English pure as any native born. We went on like that for a time until his mother come in one afternoon while the others was gone on some expedition. She stood there in her clean work clothes speaking no English at all, just Spanish words falling soft like rain. My own Spanish was poor but we managed somehow. That's when it hit me like a hammer blow. The boy could read right enough but the English letters was foreign to him, like tracks in the desert that dont match no animal you know.

I tell this tale not just to speak on the wall between languages in our schools out here in California but to show how the obvious aint always obvious at all. Even a child speaking perfect English might find reading it like crossing a river in flood. We all know this truth but what's to be done about it? For Adrian it was simple enough - teach him them letters and sounds till they was familiar as his own face in the mirror. But for them children who barely speak English at all, that's a harder path to walk.

Ain't no single answer neither. Two-language teaching, throwing them in with English speakers, private teaching, special classes - none of these alone is gonna fix what's broke. The answer lies in using all of them together like a man needs both horse and saddle to ride. The two-language way of teaching is good for all children, not just them that speak Spanish first. Studies show these children do better than their peers but folk still fear it like they fear what they dont understand. If we was to make this the rule instead of the exception, every child would profit from it. We dont need every teacher speaking two languages - that aint realistic. But we sure could use some special helpers who know both tongues, like scouts who know both sides of the border.

From the time we are young they tell us there is something greater than ourselves out there in the vast dark. Something beyond knowing. The old ones send their young to houses of God built of wood and stone and glass where they learn tales passed down through time immemorial. Some take these stories into themselves like bread and water while others cast them away, declaring themselves alone in the void. We wander through our days seeking meaning in different vessels, different shapes, trading one truth for another like worn currency. All of us searching for that pale fire in the blackness that might lead us home.

The old man said cardinal and nothing more. We set in the failing light watching the rain beat against the tin roof, smoke rising from our cigarettes like lost prayers. Water ran in the gutters and drowned the flowers that mother had planted years ago. He looked out into the gray waste of evening with eyes that seemed to see both nothing and everything at once. His clothes hung on him like a scarecrow's rags, his skull showing through the thinning hair like something unearthed. We didnt speak. What words could fill such spaces. I moved closer and we watched the rain together while the day bled out into darkness.

He died in the winter. Five days after I turned twenty-two. The doctors had given him poison to fight the poison in his blood but it only stretched his suffering like a wire drawn too tight. I cursed God in the nighttime. Sat in rooms darker than any church and spoke no prayers to the emptiness. If there was something out there listening it had turned its face from us long ago.

I did not watch him die. Could not. The witnessing of such things marks a soul in ways that cant be unnamed. I wanted him alive in my memory not cold and white in some sterile room where machines counted down his last hours. They knew, all of them, that his only son would not stand vigil at his passing. I lay in my bed for three days like Jonah in the belly of the whale waiting for word.

None came.

He was a man of the soil first and of politics second, this John Taylor of Caroline, and in him burned something fierce and righteous about the nature of freedom and the proper role of governance. The earth itself had shaped his thoughts on what a nation ought be, and from this came all else: his views on sovereignty and law and justice and the machinery of state.

The land was new then. Virgin territory for governance unmarred by the old ways that had poisoned the minds of men across the water. Taylor saw in this emptiness a terrible possibility. He knew that rights given by God or nature or whatever force breathed life into mankind were like links in an iron chain, break one and the whole thing falls to rust and ruin. These things, he reckoned, must stay beyond the reach of men who would rule other men.

Some spoke of natural states where the strong and cunning preyed upon the weak, but Taylor knew civilization must rise above such base things. He carried within him a stark vision of good and evil, like day and night with no twilight between. The government, he said, must account for both these forces dwelling in the hearts of men. Good was the protection of property and the cultivation of soil. Evil was the gathering of wealth through paper and promises. He knew that self-interest drove all men but saw how it could twist and corrupt, creating parasites who fed upon the labor of others.

The Constitution, he believed, must be read like scripture - strict but with wisdom. Let the federal government be small and bound by chains of paper and ink, for a fat government grows hungry and tyrannical. But words alone were not enough. The spirit of the law must be understood, the intentions of those who wrote it known. And above all else stood the Declaration, that first document which spoke of sovereign states joined in common cause but not merged into one great beast of governance.

He would have seen what was coming, this Caroline farmer. Would have watched the slow death of his agrarian dream with eyes that knew too well the darkness that dwelled in men's hearts when power called to them. But he planted his ideas like seeds in the furrows of a young nation's mind, and some took root and grow there still.

He stood there and looked down and the looking was a thing without emotion or connection to the world of men. His mind moved like water over stones, thoughts coming and going unbidden and unbound by the constraints of consciousness until there was nothing left but the pure act of seeing.

He'd bought the book once. An art book. Some woman who wrote about the brain and how to make it draw what the eye sees true. She wrote of frames and squares and how to parse the world into pieces small enough for a man to understand. How to take the vast terrible everything of existence and cut it down to size. But there was no frame now. No square. Just the terrible brown truth of what lay before him.

The porcelain was white as bone. White as the skulls of dead things in the desert. He touched the silver handle with fingers that knew their purpose and watched the water spiral down like some primal force of nature. The brown mass stayed. Unmoved. Uncaring. Like something ancient buried in the earth that refused to yield its secrets.

He stood in his uniform. The green tie at his throat like a noose. The mop beside him like a companion in this strange ritual. The fluorescent lights of the Rite Aid bathroom cast no shadows and in their stark truth there was nowhere to hide from what must be done. He pulled at the paper on the wall, wrapping his hand like a man preparing for war, layer upon layer until the shape of his hand was lost in the whiteness. Then he reached down into the water the way a man reaches into his own past knowing there is no good thing to find there.

The water was cold. Cold as death. Cold as truth.

They die on the roads these children. Die in twisted metal and shattered glass while the night wraps around them like a shroud. The government men in their clean white coats say the young mind aint ready for such things. That it cannot grasp the weight of steel and speed and death that comes with it. But they drive all the same.

The inexperience sits in them like poison. Makes them roll vehicles that ought not roll. Makes them press pedals that ought not be pressed. Makes them leave roads that ought to be followed. And they travel in packs these young ones. Like wolves but without the wisdom that wolves carry in their blood. Some state men in California watched them die and counted the bodies and made charts of the dead showing how they died more when they ran together.

The state tried to fix it. Made papers that said when they could drive and who could ride with them. But papers dont stop blood from flowing when metal meets metal on the midnight highways. Papers dont make young minds old.

Some doctor named Zuckerman he says even eighteen years aint enough. Says the young ones seek the thrill of it like addicts seeking poison. Says we ought to wait till the blood runs cooler in their veins. But we dont wait and they keep dying and soon there will be more of them. Children of the boomers coming up like dark clouds on the horizon ready to take their turn at the wheel.

Could make a law about it. Simple thing really. Keep them learning in schools but keep them off the roads till eighteen years have passed. Make them prove themselves like California does with their fifty hours of watching and learning. Make it the same everywhere across this blood-soaked nation.

Aint nothing new in what I say. Just truth that sits there plain as death on a highway.

They call it Central Auditory Processing Disorder and it lives in the spaces between hearing and knowing. Not in the ear itself but in the dark corridors of the brain where sound becomes meaning. Like a demon that steals understanding from the minds of those afflicted leaving them whole in body but fractured in comprehension.

The disorder moves through three territories and we will walk them all. First the nature of the thing itself. Then the marking of its presence in the afflicted, the signs writ in behavior and confusion that herald its existence. Last the methods by which those who teach might aid the cursed ones in rooms full of the blessed.

It began in the middle years of the last century. Italian men with names like Bocca and Calearo hunting for understanding in the minds of children who could hear but could not listen. They created tests. Mapped the territories of confusion. In 1977 they gathered, these searchers of broken sound, to share their dark knowledge.

The disorder manifests like a ghost in the machine of consciousness. Some cannot locate sound in space as if the world were flat and dimensionless. Some cannot parse the difference between sounds that fall like rain upon their ears. Some cannot hear the mockery in a voice or the anger beneath soft words. The sounds come but meaning dies stillborn in the mind.

They test for it now with machines and questionnaires and observations recorded in careful hands. Audiologists and speech pathologists move through the darkness of the affliction with their instruments like blind men with sticks, tapping at the walls of comprehension. They send sounds into the ear like scouts into enemy territory and measure what returns. But no single test can capture its presence fully. The disorder remains elusive, like smoke in a closed room, its origins unknown, its territory mapped but never fully conquered.

They were the lost ones. The broken ones. Children with eyes like empty wells and families splintered like old wood left too long in the sun. I knew them before I knew their names. Knew their stories written in bruises and silence. The social work, it called to me like a dark bell tolling in the night.

Service and respect aint just words writ on paper. They're carved deep in the bone. In the marrow. Ethics aint something you learn from books neither. You carry it or you dont.

I wandered them halls of learning for years, watching them young ones flee from their demons. Some found poison in the bottle, others in the needle. After Piedmont College in 09 I drifted like smoke until that summer day when fate showed its hand. There was this boy. Sixteen maybe. Sitting scared on my friend's couch like a sparrow in a thunderstorm. His parents had done things. Bad things. Dark things that leave scars deeper than skin.

I went to their house. The law was there already, blue lights cutting through the twilight like cold stars. Told them what I knew. What I'd learned in them psychology books. They asked me to talk to the parents and I did. Heard their excuses like bitter wind through dead trees. Simple disputes, they called it. Simple. Nothing simple about terror in a child's eyes.

Justice. That's what they say we got but it aint true. Society wants its people to follow like sheep. Wants em numbered and counted and sorted. But I seen different. Seen the truth of it. In school I fought against their rules like a wolf fights against the trap. Colored my hair wild colors that nature never dreamed of. Marked my flesh with metal. Stood with them that society said weren't worth standing with. Gay. Straight. Bisexual. All God's creatures carrying their own truth.

Racism and hate, they're like poison in the well. Been fighting against em since I could stand. Still am. Always will be. That's the path I chosen. Or maybe it chosen me. Either way, here I am, walking toward them dark places where children cry in the night, carrying whatever light I got left to give.

Sleep comes unbidden like a thief in the night or it doesnt come at all. The disorder they call insomnia stands before us like some dark totem carved from the bones of sleepless nights, its shadow cast long across the biological and sociocultural planes of human understanding. They who study such things speak of models and methods, of inherited traits passed down through blood and bone, and of the world that shapes us like wind shapes stone.

The categorization of sleep's absence comes in three forms, each more merciless than the last. Primary disorders stand alone like sentinels in the night. Others walk hand in hand with the demons of the mind, those axis disorders that plague mankind since time immemorial. And still others come from the poison we put in our bodies or the failing of our mortal shells.

In the realm of primary disorders there are the Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, names given by men in white coats to the horrors that stalk the night. Insomnia, that cruel mistress, denies sleep to those who seek it. Hypersomnia, her sister, drags men down into unwanted slumber like stones beneath dark water. Narcolepsy strikes like a serpent, sudden and without mercy. The Parasomnias bring their own terrors - nightmares that tear through the mind like wolves through flesh, sleep terrors that freeze the blood, and sleepwalking that sends the unconscious body wandering through the dark hours.

Deep in the hypothalamus, in the microscopic spaces between life and death, neurons fire like distant stars. They carry orexin, the messenger of wake and sleep, through channels as old as time itself. The scientists, they found these things in mice first. GABAB receptors, they called them, gatekeepers of consciousness. When they opened these gates with their chemicals and medicines, sleep came like a flood. But nature is cruel and what works in mice may not work in men. The inheritance of such mechanisms through bloodlines means some are born to wander the night while others sleep sound in their beds.

Been here two and a half years now. Four and a half semesters in this place they call University Park where the wind howls cold across empty spaces between buildings and the snow falls sideways like God's own spite. Started out in East Halls, far as you could go before hitting wilderness and stadium concrete. Stuart Hall was home then. Twenty-five minutes walking to Willard through weather that'd freeze the heart of hell itself. That's how it goes in State College.

Talked once to someone who'd been here before. Not much older but spoke of different times. Said East Halls stood alone then, separated by vast emptiness like some forsaken outpost. Now sports fields and buildings rise up from that emptiness. New Creamery. New health building. Apartments sprout like weeds in cracked earth. Campus grows like some living thing, stretching, expanding, making distance longer with each passing season.

The bicycle. That's what saves you here. Simple machine of steel and rubber but it needs more than just existing. Needs riders. Needs paths. Needs purpose.

Friend of mine found his way back to cycling after years away from it. Said he couldn't reckon why he'd ever stopped. Nothing else like it for getting around, he said, fashion be damned. Bowl of oatmeal becomes thirty miles of freedom. Living off campus now myself, far as any dorm ever was. Bought a bike. Best thing I done. Thomas building sits twenty-five minutes walking distance from where I sleep. On the bike, five minutes if you're willing to push. Pollock Road runs straight as an arrow but it ain't friendly. Not to bikes. Not to nothing really.

Walking's got its merits sure enough but time ain't one of them. Thirty minutes extra each way to Thomas. Two and a half hours gone each week like smoke in wind. More when you count everything else needs doing. Time's a currency can't be borrowed back once spent. Bike saves what little I got left of it.

They had come to see what the old man Huxley had writ about the machines and the money and how they worked together like serpents in the dark. In his book about the brave world that was to come he showed them people who lived not as ones but as many, folks who sought nothing but the quick pleasure of the moment like animals rutting in the field. And above them all stood the Controller like some dark god, moving his pieces across a board none could see.

The dead prophets of old had spoke of such things. Marx and his ilk who saw how the powerful made the weak believe lies about their own chains. In this new world they had built the people were less than cattle, branded and sorted by letters like freight in a trainyard. Deltas. Gammas. Names that meant nothing and everything. They filled their heads with whispered commands while they slept, telling them to spend and want and need until there wasnt nothing left inside them that was their own.

Weren't no real love in this place neither. The people moved through their days like ghosts, touching but never feeling, speaking but never saying. The men talked of women like they was discussing livestock, measuring their worth in flesh and curves they called pneumatic. The women were no better, trading stories of their rutting like they was discussing the weather. Each class of folk stayed in their place like it was writ in stone, believing the lies they'd been fed since before they could walk. They consumed and obeyed and never looked up to see the bars of their cage, thinking themselves free while wearing chains they'd been taught to love.

The Controller watched it all from his high tower, knowing what Marx knew - that if you tell a man he's special while you rob him blind, he'll thank you for the privilege. And so they went on, all of them, dancing to music they couldn't hear, played by hands they couldn't see.

Four years past I sat in a room where they spoke of Islam. The question hung in the air like woodsmoke, heavy and acrid. Whether this faith carried violence in its bones. The years since the towers fell have shifted like desert sands, the wind of public opinion blowing first one way then another, media voices crying hostility then tolerance in equal measure. Now we stand in a time where a man called Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his lineage, could reach for the highest seat in the land. Such things were not dreamt of in the days when the towers still stood.

The Prophet's tale troubles me. It moves against what history whispers, like two streams flowing contrary. I had known Muhammad as a conqueror, a man who bent tribes to his will and branded their souls with his faith through steel and fire. Yet these pages paint him gentle, a lamb among wolves, suffering the slings of men until they saw truth in his words and came crawling through the dust to drink from his wisdom. 

They write of miracles that echo like mockingbirds singing borrowed songs. Mutton and milk multiplied like Christ's loaves and fishes, feeding forty when it should have fed few. The writers craft their prophet in borrowed robes, dressing him in the cast-off garments of the Nazarene. They diminish Christ's glory by making their prophet wear his face like a mask.

Their stories come wrapped in layers of telling, each voice more distant than the last. They say this man told that man who heard from another, words passing through countless mouths like water through too many vessels, each one losing something in the pouring. They meant these tellings to be proof but they stand as hollow as desert bones bleached by sun and time.

What gnaws at the mind is how they shape him soft and holy, this Muhammad. A gentle soul dispensing wisdom like morning dew. But history tells another tale, written in blood and conquest, and I wonder if those who follow him now know the true shape of the man whose name they praise. The past carries its own truth, and no amount of gentle words can wash the blood from its pages.

They cast off his teachings like old clothes. Left them there in the dust of history while they marched forward with their own designs. The truth of it lay bare and bleeding in the centuries that followed, each generation stepping further from the source like concentric rings in dead water. Yet now something stirs in the minds of men. Some ancient knowing. The old guard stands fast with their dogma but their numbers thin like shadows at noon.

The Christians will remember. They will look back across the waste of years and see what was lost. What was added. Layer upon layer of doctrine like rust on pure metal. It may take generations, maybe more, but time bends back on itself like a snake eating its tail. They'll strip away the accumulated weight of centuries, peeling back the years like old paint until nothing remains but the raw wood of his words, unvarnished and true.

When this knowing sweeps across the old countries like wildfire, burning away the chaff of centuries, the church will abide. But it will be changed. The countless branches of belief will draw together like scattered cattle before a storm. The differences between them will blur and fade like old photographs left in the sun. Unity will rise from diversity like a phoenix from ash.

History moves in great circles. The Romans who fed Christians to lions knelt before crosses in time. The land that chains broke now bears black leaders. And so too will Christianity circle back to its source, seeking truth in the bones of its beginning. They'll read his words anew, not as stone tablets but as living things, metaphors breathing in the mind.

Before all this there was only Judaism. Before Rome planted its eagles in Jerusalem in the year 63 before Christ. The one God, the holy books, the revealed truth - these were the pillars. But even then the people split like light through crystal - Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots, and the common folk who walked between them all.

The darkness that dwells in men's hearts aint no mystery and The Jungle shows it plain as day. Like wolves they are, prowling through the night, seeking only their own fortunes and caring nothing for the weak that fall beneath their feet. The book lays it bare and cold and true.

You see it most in them factory bosses, them kings of industry who sit high in their towers of brick and iron. They build their empires on broken backs and spilled blood, their only god being the almighty dollar. Sinclair writes of how them buildings stood against the sky like ancient ruins, dark towers belching forth rivers of smoke that stretched on forever into the void, as if hell itself had opened its maw upon the earth. The owners, they didnt care none about what their machines did to the air or how their waste poisoned the ground. The rivers ran thick with blood and offal from ten thousand beasts, but profit was their only truth.

The workers was nothing more than meat to them. Expendable. Replaceable. Like Sinclair says, the whole place was nothing but a cauldron of hate, where a man's worth was measured only in coins. They'd work a man till his hands bled and his spirit broke, then cast him aside like a spent shell casing. No warning. No mercy. Just the cold mathematics of greed.

In them days there weren't no laws to protect the weak. No safety nets. No guardian angels. The factory was a beast that fed on flesh and bone, grinding up immigrants and poor folk alike in its terrible machinery. Them that lived in Packingtown was caught in a web of misery with no escape, like flies in a spider's web. The unions that claimed to help was just another kind of parasite, feeding off the desperation of them that had nothing left to give.

They called it progress but it was slavery by another name. As Sinclair put it, them foreign folk and poor people was hanging by a thread, their very existence dependent on the whims of men no better than slave drivers of old. And just like them ancient slavers, these modern masters bred the same rot in men's souls, the same darkness that turns brother against brother and makes monsters of men.

They say Dreamland was one of them poems Poe held dear above the others. Word was he took to writing bout some place called Thulé, twice marking it in his verses like a man marking the start and end of his territory. Virgil knew of this place too, wrote of it in times long past, called it an island past Britain where the known world gave way to darkness. But there was something else, something closer to our time that bore watching.

Poe had himself a powerful thirst for German writing, deep and relentless as any desert wanderer. There was this man Goethe, wrote himself a thing called Faust, published in two pieces like a broken mirror, first part in 1808, second when death came calling for him in 32. Inside that second piece lay hidden a darker tale, The King of Thulé they called it. Story goes of a king whose woman died leaving him nothing but a goblet and memories that drove him to drink. Grief ate at him like rust on iron till he gave everything away save that cup, walked himself to the edge of the world and cast it into the black waters below, then closed his eyes for the last time.

You can see the shadows of one man's writing in the other's, like blood seeping through floorboards. Both speaking of loss and drink and darkness. Both walking through lands where the sun fears to tread. Poe took that word Thulé and made it his own in The Pit and Pendulum, then again in Dreamland, bookending his verses like a man marking his grave at both ends.

In Dreamland the speaker wanders through a world stripped of color, haunted by ghosts of them that's gone before, like some dark mirror of Goethe's grieving king. Both men, separated by ocean and years, writing bout the same darkness, same loneliness, same weight of memory that drives men to drink and death.

Weren't no accident neither. Poe knew Goethe's work like a man knows the scars on his own hands. Had to, being the kind that followed Tennyson's writings close as a shadow. The German's words was everywhere in them days, spreading like wildfire through the minds of them that read, and Poe, he was always one to watch the flames.

The law speaks of malice and punishment in the sunbaked streets of California where a woman fell and broke herself upon the tiled floor of a market. The floor gleamed wet with spilled applesauce like some pale blood of commerce and the manager sat in his office eating his dinner while the world turned and customers walked the aisles unwarned.

They had told him twice. First Wayne and then Haddigan coming to his door like prophets of some minor doom and he had turned them away with words about time and dinner and things that could wait. But things that wait carry their own judgment and at half past five Palmer found the slick spot that waited patient as a snake and fell. Her back broke or near enough to it. The fifth such falling in that year alone, as if the store itself hungered for broken bodies upon its floor.

The question of punishment lies cold as stone in the hands of judges who must weigh despicable acts against the letter of civil code. Section 3294 speaks of malice like some ancient text, defining the darkness in men's hearts when they know the danger that waits and yet do nothing. The manager knew. He had seen five others fall in that same year, their bodies marking the calendar of his negligence like stations of some retail cross.

The courts have spoken before of such things. In Taylor they drew the lines between simple failure and willful disregard, between accident and malice. They spoke of men who see the consequences coming like dark riders on the horizon and choose to let them ride. The manager saw them coming. Twice warned and twice he waved them on, choosing his dinner over the safety of those who walked his aisles in trust.

The law will not dismiss this easily. It will weigh the manager's indifference against the broken body of Palmer and find there something more than simple neglect. Something that speaks of conscious choice and willing blindness to consequence. Something that carries the weight of punishment beyond mere compensation.

The wanting had been there always. A void that would not fill. It came upon her in her fourteenth year like some dark spirit that takes hold and will not loose its grip and even now three years hence it remained steadfast and cruel in its persistence. She knew now it was not a thing she sought but a someone and yet no boy had stirred her heart. They came to her with their fumbling advances and their awkward words but she felt nothing. She questioned this strangeness in herself, this absence of desire that seemed to mark her different from other girls her age. Years of thinking on it had yielded nothing but hollow theories that crumbled like ash in her hands.

The house was quiet most days. Her parents moved through life like two leaves carried by the same stream, never quarreling, never raising voices except when their daughter's wild spirit threatened to break free of their gentle waters. She was their opposite, full of light and motion, drawing others to her like moths to flame yet carrying in her heart a kindness that made her beloved by all who knew her.

But this day was different. This day carried death in its teeth. She wandered the rooms seeking something unnamed when her mother's scream cut through the silence like a blade. She found the woman sprawled on the kitchen floor, pain twisting her face into something ancient and terrible. Mama, she said. Mama what's wrong. The words came broken and gasping. Hospital, her mother said. Take me. The girl lifted her mother like a child, thankful for the strength in her arms that she had built over years. She carried her to the car and laid her in the back like some precious cargo and drove through streets that seemed suddenly foreign and hostile.

The hospital rose before them like a white monument to suffering. Inside the air hung thick with chemicals and fear but the girl noticed none of it, her world narrowed to the woman in her arms. She called out and white-coated figures appeared like ghosts, wheeling a narrow bed between them. They took her mother away down corridors that seemed to stretch into forever and left her alone with her thoughts in a plastic chair that had held countless others before her, all waiting, all afraid.

Later they would tell her how her mother had reached for something beautiful, a simple vase high up where such things are kept, and how the stool had betrayed her like all simple things sometimes do.

They sought truth in numbers and blood. The Mediterranean way of eating, ancient as the olive groves themselves, whispered promises of longer life through the statistical dark. Not the diet of their fathers but something older still. Plant foods and fish flesh and the oils that run golden, not white like the rendered fats of beasts. The drink too, measured and portioned like sacrament.

They had seen it before in other studies, dark auguries in the data that showed how death came slower to those who followed the old ways. The heart's betrayals less frequent, the body's weight held in check. But none had looked deep into the darkness of the stroke, that thief of mind and movement.

They gathered their witchcraft of numbers from seventy-four thousand eight hundred and eighty-six women, all nurses, scattered across eleven states like seeds in wind. None had the sugar sickness nor the heart's early warnings. For twenty years they watched and waited, gathering their testimonies six times over, asking what passed their lips and in what measure. The women marked their papers faithful as penitents, year after year, more than nineteen in twenty staying true to the cause.

When death came they searched the records, the cold files of hospitals, the certificates that mark a life's end. Some they called probable, lacking the certainty of paper proof, but these too they counted in their ledger of loss. They weighed all things: the smoke in their lungs, the pills they took, the blood that ceased its monthly flow, the sweat of their leisure hours.

Through machines that counted and sorted they fed their numbers, adjusting for the chaos of living, for age and smoke and flesh and movement. And in the end the truth came clear as bones in desert sand. Those who followed closest the Mediterranean way, they died less from the heart's failings and the brain's dark floods. In numbers it showed: two thousand three hundred ninety-one hearts stopped or wounded, one thousand seven hundred sixty-three minds darkened by stroke's shadow, one thousand seventy-seven souls taken by the combined assault of heart and brain.

The numbers spoke their truth. Those who ate as the ancients ate, they lived longer than their sisters who did not. This was the power of old wisdom written in modern blood.

Hitler lives, the sign reads. Just that and nothing more.

The girl stands at the corner holding cardboard above her head like some prophet of old. Dark ink bleeding into the corrupted pulp. Burma they call it now though names mean nothing in such places where men with guns make their own truth. Since sixty-two the soldiers have ruled there, taking power like thieves in the night, their boots echoing down empty streets where democracy once walked.

They came in saffron robes, the monks did. Walking the streets like fire made flesh, their procession a silent scream against the military that ruled their world. At first the government let them be but violence has its own gravity and soon enough the night was filled with the sound of splintering temple doors and the wet thud of rifle butts against flesh. The foreign writers disappeared into concrete cells or wooden boxes. A Japanese man named Nagai bled out on the street, his camera still clicking as his life leaked away into the dust.

Thirteen dead they say. But the colonel who fled speaks of thousands. Bodies stacked like cordwood in the jungle night. The truth of it lost to the darkness like so many truths before.

These things are old as time itself. Rome's emperors claimed divine right while they burned the world. The sons of heaven rule Japan still, their divinity unchanged by cars and computers and ritual death. Here in our own land the president speaks to holy men who sell salvation like carnival barkers hawking painted shells.

The stories repeat. Tiananmen Square ran red while tanks ground students into the pavement. Rwanda's machetes flashed in the sun as neighbor killed neighbor. Hitler's ovens burned day and night until the sky itself turned gray with ash.

And still we stand here, holding signs against the darkness, as if paper and ink could stop bullets and hate.

The ghost of Duke Ellington haunts the halls of jazz like some dark specter that won't lay down to rest, his presence carved deep into the bones of music by years that stretched longer than most men dare dream. At the piano his touch was light as morning dew but in the composition of sound he was more akin to some mad architect building cathedrals of brass and wood and breath. He knew the souls of his players like a father knows his sons and he built frameworks of notes wherein they could wander free as wild horses or march strict as soldiers depending on what the music called for.

The sound lived in him and through him and he knew how to make it speak in tongues both strange and beautiful. Each player was a color on his palette and he painted with them all, making pictures in the air that no man had seen before and few since have matched. The dictionary men speak of something called Creole Love Call where he took the human voice and stripped it bare of words, leaving only pure sound like some primal thing that crawled up from the swamp of time.

The piece moves like this: First comes the voice pure as spring water calling out to reeds that answer back, the voice growing rough like old leather toward the end. Then a trumpet muted and crying blue notes into the darkness. A clarinet soars high above while the piano whispers secrets underneath. The whole band takes up the call then, brass and reeds speaking back and forth like lovers in the night. At the height of it all the reeds cry out high and wild while brass and rhythm punch holes in time itself. Then back to the beginning it goes, voice and reeds once more, but now the voice has learned to growl like some beast that's found its way into church. It ends with a woman's voice running wild and a trombone speaking blasphemy.

In Hot and Bothered he took Miley's trumpet and Cox's voice and made them dance together like they was kin, trumpet singing like a man and voice playing like brass. Later in It Don't Mean a Thing he let Nanton loose with that muted trombone of his, and if there's any sound in this world that can tell you what a soul in torment sounds like, that's the one.

The shells carry their own mathematics, though men have long stood dumb before their geometries. In 1917 Thompson spoke true when he said that no zoologist had yet dreamed in the language of numbers what nature had wrought in bone and calcium, and his words echo still across the century like the voice of some dead prophet.

The mollusks build their homes in spiral paths through time and space, each revolution marking another turn in their blind journey through existence. These whorls, as men name them, spiral around an axis that ain't there except in theory, like the pole star that guides men through darkness but exists only in their minds. The columella stands as the spine of the thing, anchoring each whorl to the next in an ancient agreement between flesh and mineral.

We took their ghosts in X-ray light and fed their numbers to machines that could speak their language. The software called CerioShell consumed these measurements like some digital oracle, spitting forth predictions of forms that might be or might have been. We sought to understand the boundaries of what could exist, as if mapping the territories between the possible and impossible.

The shell grows like a testament to time itself, each revolution marking another cycle in the endless wheel of life and death. The suture line divides yesterday from today, while the body whorl stands as the final chapter in the creature's autobiography writ in calcium. The spire reaches upward like the tower of some prehistoric babel, its apex pointing toward heaven or whatever lies beyond.

Through the aperture the living thing reaches out into the world, that opening like a door between two realms - one of flesh and one of stone. We studied these shells from every angle - apical, basal, apertural - seeking in their symmetries some truth about the laws that govern all living things.

To count the whorls is to count chapters in a book written in the language of survival. Draw a line where the first suture begins and follow it through space like tracking the path of a star across the night sky. Each quarter turn tells its own story.

The mathematics of their existence can be captured, contained in formulae that describe the path of that opening through space and time. But numbers alone cant tell the whole truth of it. They are like marks on a map that show the way but not the journey.

They watched the numbers like dark harbingers on the page. Ten years gone and the dead babies in Indonesia lay just as numerous as before, small corpses in their mothers' arms like broken birds. The country had met some of its promises, water flowing cleaner now through pipes and sewers, but the children and their mothers kept dying all the same. The reasons lay scattered like bones in the sand, waiting to be counted.

In the villages and towns the midwives came more often now, seven births in ten seeing their weathered hands. But these women, these healers of old ways, stood powerless when the blood came too fast and too much, when death rode in on a crimson tide. The numbers spoke false comfort. And fewer children with the bloody flux saw proper doctors now, their mothers carrying them home to wait out their fever dreams, some to wake and some to sleep eternal.

The knife-birth, the cesarean, rare as rain in the dry season. Four in hundred mothers felt its mercy. In the cities it came more often, seven mothers in hundred saved by the blade, but in the far places only two. The poor watched their sisters die while the rich lived on, a gap wide as twenty-seven graves between them. Money spoke here as it spoke everywhere, deciding who lived and who returned to dust.

They argued now about the path forward, whether to build towers of specific care or strengthen the whole edifice of healing. The targeted way beckoned like a mirage, promising quick victory, but carried poison in its heart. When money flowed to one wound, others festered untended. The helpers followed the coin like crows to carrion, leaving other sufferers to their fate. And in their haste they built parallel roads to the same destination, wasting precious time with papers and forms, duplicate wheels spinning in the sand while mothers bled and babies died in the dark.

The music they called Popular had grown wild and uncontrollable like kudzu in summer heat, sprawling across a hundred years of human sound until no man could count its tendrils or name its parts. Within its vast territory lay kingdoms of sound - rap and rock and country and jazz and folk - but these too had split and divided like cells beneath a microscope, spawning bastard children that grew teeth and claws of their own.

Among these dark offspring Heavy Metal stood tallest, most terrible in its beauty. For forty years it had grown and mutated, showing faces both beautiful and grotesque, faces that spoke of rage and despair and sometimes joy though mostly it dwelt in shadows. The darkness called to others and they came, bearing guitars like weapons, and each who came carved out their own territory in the night until the territories became uncountable.

Now the metal stands fractured, its boundaries fluid as mercury. What it is or aint no one can rightly say. It drinks deep from other wells of sound but its origins remain, black as pitch and twice as thick. To know the metal you must know its heart, must understand that it aint just music but a movement of souls through darkness.

The movement feeds on excess like a fever. More bass more volume more violence more theater until the ears bleed and the mind screams. Them that play it are masters of their craft, fingers flying across strings like spiders weaving webs of sound. In the seventies they found the drugs, or the drugs found them, and the music turned strange and otherworldly, like messages from some terrible heaven. It spoke truths other music dared not speak, reaching into places where light feared to go. Some say it draws power from them old Romantic composers, them that knew the darkness before electricity gave it voice. The proof's in the words they sing, black poetry that bleeds onto the page.

When the Beatles wrote Helter Skelter they opened a door they maybe didn't mean to open. That song carried the sickness in it, the up-and-down fever dream of chemical paradise. Some call it the first real Metal song, though it was just them trying to outdo them Rolling Stones, to prove they could walk in darkness too. They put it on that white album like a black seed in white soil, never knowing what would grow from it.

In the years before the dreamers came with their twisted visions and their canvases of madness there was another who walked alone in the gardens of his mind. Rousseau was his name and he painted what he saw there. The Dream they called it, this thing he made in 1910, this vision of a woman lost in some verdant paradise, though it was more than that. It was his own yearning made manifest, his hunger for acclaim that gnawed at him like some desperate animal.

He carried within him two warring spirits. One whispered of conformity, of following the paths others had worn smooth with their passing. The other spoke of wildness, of walking where none had walked before. These spirits clashed and bled within him all the days of his life.

The man himself came into the world in Laval, a town in the French northwest, in the year 1844. His father worked metal and sold hardware and knew something of comfort though not of wealth. The boy grew without learning the ways of art, became instead a collector of tolls for the state until he had seen forty winters pass. They called him douanier though this was wrong, he being merely a gabelou, a distinction that mattered little to any but those who wore such titles.

Death stalked him as it stalks all men but showed particular cruelty in taking eight of his children before they drew more than a handful of breaths each. Then it took his wife Clémence leaving him with only the girl Julia and a grief that sat in him like stone. He turned to painting then as a drowning man turns to any floating thing, hoping it might bear his weight and carry him to some distant shore.

He worked in the shadow of giants. Matisse and others were rising then, their stars ascending while he labored in obscurity. Matisse feared the common and fought against it with every stroke of his brush while Rousseau sought it like a lover, thinking perhaps that in perfect conformity he might find perfect acceptance. But the heart wants what it wants and his brush followed paths of its own choosing, leading him through strange forests of the mind where no other had ventured.

They say truth and beauty walk together like old companions across the wasteland of mans thoughts. Keats knew it when he wrote them words about the urn, that beauty was truth and truth was beauty and that was all any man needed to know in this world. Most things we learn come from books or the hard ways of life but these twin riders of truth and beauty they come to us like ghosts in the night unbidden and unexplained. We dont learn them so much as recognize them like the face of someone we knew before we were born.

You can talk about what makes something right or beautiful but you'll never catch its soul in your words. Like trying to describe the Mona Lisa. You can go on about shadow and light and what them Italian painters was thinking but in the end its just wind. People look at something beautiful and they say theres just something about it and then they try to explain but the explaining aint never enough. Same with whats right and wrong. OConnor knew it. Said you tell stories cause regular words wont do. Wittgenstein knew it too. Said ethics was beyond telling.

The connection twixt right and beautiful runs deeper than most think. Both of them hit you in places you cant name, like getting struck by lightning but the burns aint visible. Literature carries this burden more than other arts cause it deals in the currency of human souls. McKean wrote that moral standards might not matter much to music but they matter to stories like they matter to life itself. Stories traffic in values like a merchant trades in gold and the values is what makes them precious to us.

We recognize the truth of this like we recognize the shadow of death. It aint something you can point to or measure with any tools made by man. Its just there, waiting in the dark corners of our understanding, patient as stones, eternal as the desert night.

The Germany that stands now rises like some ancient beast from the earth, its spine the alps at München stretching north through darkness and light to where the Baltic waters lap at Kiel's cold shores. This same spirit moves through the land like blood through veins, from Köln where the Rhine cuts deep to Dresden where the Elbe winds dark and knowing. That such a thing should come from many sources surprises no man who knows the way of tribes and blood and earth.

Germania. The name itself carries weight like old bones in the ground, disputed by men who claim to know its truth but find only shadows. Tacitus wrote of the Tungrians who crossed the Rhine, their name changing like wind-blown sand from German to something else, something older. Caesar too spoke the word Germanus in his writings of war and conquest, taking it from Gaulish tongues to mark those he had broken from those he had not. Some say it meant neighbor in that old speech, others claim it spoke of spears or of shouting, but such meanings are lost now like footprints in snow.

In the year ninety-eight Tacitus put down in words what he knew of these people, claiming them pure as winter water, untouched by the mixing of blood that marked other lands. Who indeed, he asked, would leave warm southern shores for this wild country with its gray skies and darker woods, unless it were already written in their blood?

The Romans came but did not stay, their armies moving like shadows across the land, taking what they would and retreating south again to their marble halls and painted walls. The Germanic tribes lived in the spaces between, trading what the forest gave them, selling their strength to Roman generals who knew the worth of men who had grown strong in hard places. They lived thus on the edge of empire, neither fully in nor fully out, like wolves at the firelight's edge.

In the dark theater of deception that is Twelfth Night there runs a truth cold and stark as winter bone. That a mask once worn becomes more than mere covering but a second skin that must be torn away lest it consume the wearer whole. And in the tearing there is blood and there are those who would turn away from such revelation.

The matter of gender masquerade carries its own particular poison. What darkness in the soul drives one to shed their given form and take up another. For Viola the answer comes like a whispered prayer in the night. Preservation. Survival. The ancient instinct of prey. "I'll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count..." The words hang in the air like smoke.

She walks the path of manhood and finds herself cut off from the sisterhood that might have sheltered her. A lone wolf in sheep's clothing. And the deception breeds its own complications dark and twisted as roots beneath the earth. Olivia's heart turns toward this false man with the fervor of religious conversion. "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay." The words fall like dead leaves. And there is Orsino too whose own desires wreath around Viola like thorned vines: "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me."

Perhaps to modern eyes the play speaks to deeper truths buried beneath custom and propriety like bones beneath soil. The deception acts as spade turning earth revealing what lies beneath. Olivia's passion for Cesario might speak to hidden waters running deep but more likely stands as Shakespeare's mirror held up to those who would judge the book by its binding. This truth reveals itself when she turns from Cesario to Sebastian quick as a snake striking, claiming the disguised Viola not as lover but blood: "A sister, you are she." The words final as a coffin lid closing.

They spoke of the German rule in those lands as something brutal and dark, a thing that carried with it the weight of genocide and the blood of the Ovaherero and Nama peoples who walked those scorched plains. But empires aint simple things and cant be marked by single deeds no matter how terrible. The Germans ruled different in different places and that's the truth of it.

In the east where the land was green they left behind them educated men who could read and write and cipher and when the British came in 1919 they found these men and knew their worth. In Kamerun too they done the same and visitors wrote of it with approval in their books.

But South West Africa was different. Different in a way that cant be explained by simple tellings. While the government built schools in the east and taught the natives there, in the southwest they gave that task to the missionaries and gave them little help besides. Yet they poured money like water into schools for the white children, both government schools and mission schools alike. These choices echoed long after the Germans were gone. While other colonies had natives who could read and write and make their mark in the world, in South West Africa most remained in darkness, untouched by learning's light.

The land itself told part of the tale. It was a hard country, mostly desert, but with enough temperance in its climate to draw white settlers like moths to flame. By 1913 they numbered fifteen thousand souls, three times more than lived in East Africa which was the next most settled of their lands. The settlers came and with them came their notions and their prejudices and their fears, and these things shaped the way the teaching was done or wasnt done, depending on whose children needed learning.

The old books tell of this time, most wrote in German when the empire still stood or in the years right after. Later came the English writers who looked deeper, compared one place to another, sought to understand why things were done the way they were done. A man named Cohen wrote of it, of how the settlers changed everything, though maybe he didnt see all the darkness that lay beneath.

Blood and dust marked the path between these two nations, stretching fifty-seven years across the scarred earth like a wound that would not heal. The republic to the north and the republic to the south, each eyeing the other across that vast expanse of desert and mountain where men died nameless deaths beneath an indifferent sun.

They fought their war in forty-six, the Americans coming down like locusts, taking Texas and the Southwest territories in a storm of gunpowder and manifest destiny. But the war was just the center of it. Before and after there were skirmishes and raids, men crossing invisible lines drawn by men who had never seen the land they divided. The people of these nations carried old hatreds like sacred relics, passed down from Spanish galleons and English sailing ships, from cathedrals and protestant churches where each cursed the other's god in different tongues.

The border between them was like a rope pulled taut, vibrating with tension. Such is the way of nations that share earth and sky but not blood or belief. The Americans looked south and saw papistry and monarchy, things their grandfathers had fled across an ocean to escape. The Mexicans looked north and saw heretics and usurpers, come to take what was never theirs to claim.

Bandits and raiders moved across this divide like wraiths, striking at settlements and vanishing back across the line, caring nothing for flags or treaties. Seventeen times the nations clashed in those years, each clash marked in ledgers and books but written truly in blood on the desert floor. The raids continued until both armies came to the frontier, and even then the peace was bought with steel and lead.

The old rivalry died slow, like all things born of hate and fear. Mexico bent like a reed in an American wind, and the northern republic's hunger changed from land to gold, from conquest to commerce. But the memory of those years lies still in the earth, in the bones of the nameless dead, in the wind that blows across two nations that once stained the desert red.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like most afflictions but sudden and complete, a thief in the night stealing what was mine to keep. I didn't even know such a malady existed in this world.

I was a nurse then. Chose it out of some primitive need for safety, the kind that was absent in my youth. They'd say you'll always find work, always have bread, for the sick and dying never cease their coming. So I buried my dreams of science and words and took up the mantle of healing, though it healed nothing in me.

Then there I stood. Forty-six winters gone and alone, pockets empty as a desert well, body betraying every command. Still am. Fifteen years living off the government's mercy and everything I owned has scattered to the wind like autumn leaves. Each dawn brings its own war, its own assault on what little certainty remains. Nothing solid to grasp except one truth: without the blood-bonds of family and the handful who stayed, I'd have been dust. When the real darkness comes, ain't nobody feels strong.

Life brings its calamities, big and small, like storm clouds gathering on a horizon you can't outrun. No matter how you fortify against it, some tempests are too mighty to weather alone.

These United States need weaning from the government teat, true enough. That basket's rotted clean through. But better we learn to trust our own kind again, to reach out hands both ways - helping and accepting help - than each soul digging their own hole to hide in.

They speak of rugged individualism like it's gospel, but what kept our ancestors breathing wasn't the lone wolf spirit. It was breaking bread together, sharing what little they had, knowing a neighbor's need was your own. Them wagon trains that crossed the Rockies didn't make it on solitary courage.

Be ready, sure. Got my own cache of supplies - medical stuff, water tablets, window coverings against whatever poison might come floating on the wind. Got light for the darkness and food for the hunger. If you've got land to work and knowledge to preserve its bounty, do it. Ain't no shame in preparation.

But while you're stocking up, learn your neighbor's name. Might be the most important preparation of all.

In the ancient times before Christ walked the earth there was born a prince who would come to be known as Buddha and he walked the earth and saw the suffering of men and cast off his worldly possessions like a snake sheds its skin and found enlightenment in the barren places where men go to die. And from his teachings came forth Buddhism and chief among its sects was Theravada and it endured through the centuries like a stone worn smooth by water. Twenty five hundred years have passed and the religion has changed like all things must change and you can see it in Sri Lanka where they cut the waters in ceremony each year and the monks and common folk gather though Buddha spoke nothing of such things in his time. The changes run deeper than mere ceremony and reach into the very marrow of salvation itself. The keepers of the faith both robed and common have altered their sacred principles as time passed like wind reshaping the desert and these changes came from within and without like thieves in the night some bearing knives and some bearing nothing at all.

They speak of forces internal and external like twin serpents coiled around the faith. The internal force rises from those who call themselves Buddhist be they monk or layman and the external comes from those who stand outside the faith like wolves at the edge of firelight. And some forces come with malice burning in their hearts seeking to tear down what Buddha built and these they call hostile while others neither help nor harm but move through the world like dust storms that care nothing for what lies in their path and these they call benign.

At its heart the faith holds certain truths like ancient bones buried in deep earth. They seek shelter in three things: the Buddha himself and the Dhamma which is the word and the Sangha which is the community of faithful. The word is kept in three vessels they call pitakas and these contain all manner of things from rules to stories to the nature of what lies beyond the veil of flesh. They speak of there being no soul and of suffering that clings to life like smoke to cloth and of how nothing lasts and nothing stays and all things must pass away. Only by knowing these truths can a man break free from the wheel of death and rebirth that turns eternal like a millstone grinding souls to dust. And when enlightenment comes it burns away desire and hatred and the fog of delusion that clouds men's minds. They have rules for living both for the common man who must not kill or lie or steal or rut like beasts or poison his mind with strong drink and for the monks who carry heavier burdens still. But above all else they hold to four noble truths that speak of suffering and its causes and its end like a map leading out of darkness.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are.
