	In discussing next steps towards improving neonatal and maternal care indicators, the most basic question is how to most effectively address the lack of service.  Specifically, should Indonesia develop program-specific approaches or strengthen the overall health system without focusing on pre and post-pregnancy care for the mother and child.  There is no question that programmatic approaches to solve the problems outlined above are attractive.  Not only do “vertical approaches” that target one sector of improvements have much more targeted, manageable objectives, they also generally generate faster results.  There are some drawbacks to keep in mind, however.  One major drawback is that investing heavily in programming for one particular area of the health sector often means that funding for other areas suffers and human resources will flock towards working in that area that has more resources (the effect of international funding to HIV/AIDS and its effect on the family planning sector is one example).  In addition, running multiple parallel programs for one area results in duplication of services that are also uncoordinated between programs.  This leads to an increase in forms and paperwork for supplies and funding.

‎	‏The classification of Popular Music has grown over the past‭ ‬100‭ ‬years to include so many genres that it is difficult to definitively list them all. Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music. Metal is also—although it may not come as a surprise—a movement that is heavily drug induced. There was a psychedelic drug boom in the mid-70‭’‬s that led to people getting crazier,‭ ‬leading to them to make crazy,‭ ‬other-worldly records,‭ ‬using the drugs as a scapegoat for their creation. It possesses many dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities,‭ ‬which was very new to the music scene because a large amount of popular music had qualities that weren’t true to the darker side of the emotional spectrum. Also,‭ ‬later generations of metal have taken some of their influence from the dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities that were so present in the Romantic Era. Lyrics such as the following express the darkness that is such a staple of the movement:‭ (‬Byrne‭)‬


	
These lyrics from Helter Skelter display the darker side of the Beatles. It exhibits an up and down,‭ ‬supposedly that of drugs. This song is considered by some to be one of the first Heavy Metal songs. It was a response to a Rolling Stones song that was also on the heavier,‭ ‬darker side. The Beatles wanted to prove that they could be just as heavy as the Stones,‭ ‬so they put that song on‭ ‬The White Album.

A few decades before the Surrealist artists began painting their dreamlike works, the artist Henri Rousseau was carefully crafting his own dreams, literally and figuratively. The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
Culture moves like a ghost through the rooms of negotiation, unseen yet heavy with presence. It aint what you think it is and it aint what you dont think it is neither. There aint no single truth to it no more than there's a single truth to man. Those who say all Russians are this way or all Japanese are that way speak with tongues of children, knowing nothing of the dark waters that run beneath such simple words.

The negotiator who comes to foreign soil carries with him the weight of his own world like a stone in his pocket. He measures what he sees against what he knows and sometimes the measuring dont add up right. Sometimes it dont add up at all.

You could spend your days studying the history books or walking the streets where the people you aim to know have walked. But judgment aint the way. The way is acceptance, cold and pure as mountain water. This is doubly true when you come to the table bearing a weaker hand, like a man bringing a knife to a gunfight. And if youre standing on their ground, you best mind their ways and their beliefs, lest the ground shift beneath your feet and leave you standing in nothing but air.

But culture aint just about nations and borders drawn in sand and blood. Companies got their own way too, their own rituals like ancient tribes. Some demand their people wear suits like armor, others let them come as they please. Some speak straight and true, others dance around words like moths round a flame. Even in America, where the corporate towers rise like steel mountains, each floor, each room might hold its own truth, its own way of being.

The why of it all, thats what matters most. Values run deeper than river water, darker than cave shadows. In some places a man would sooner die than shame his people in public. In others, the deal itself is sacred as scripture. You got to know these things before you sit at their table, before you break their bread. But knowing the man across from you, that's the real key. That's the lock that needs turning.

The negotiator who forgets these truths is like a blind man walking in a field of snakes. He might make it across, but the odds aint in his favor.

The fool speaks of godlessness and in his speaking damns himself to darkness. These words echo from ancient psalms and rest heavy in the writings of Anselm, that old saint who sought to prove what cannot be proven. And Aquinas too, though separated by time and dust and blood, carried this same burden. They walked different paths but sought the same truth, and we must judge them as men seeking one God, not many, for to do otherwise would be to wander from the track like a blind dog in the desert night.

Neither found the whole of it. That's the truth of it.

Anselm's words came like wind through dead leaves, speaking of understanding through faith, as if God could be found in the caverns of man's mind alone. He said that because we can think of God we must accept his existence, like a man who dreams of water in the desert and believes the dream itself proves there are springs beneath the sand. The logic winds tight as a snare, but catches nothing substantial. Faith, they call it in their books and temples. Faith like a flame in darkness.

But Aquinas walked a different road. He believed God could be proven like a theorem, laid bare under the knife of reason until the truth bled out clear as morning. He built five towers of logic, each one reaching toward heaven: change, cause, necessity, perfection, and the terrible harmony of all things. Like a man finding tracks in the sand and knowing without seeing that something passed this way. God must exist, he said, because the world demands it. As if the universe itself was a puzzle with one piece missing and that piece must be God because nothing else would fit the void.

The truth of it lay somewhere between their words, maybe. Or maybe it lay nowhere at all. But their arguments stand like ancient stones in the desert, weathered but unmoving, and we who come after must make what sense of them we can.

Words carry weight and writers know this truth deep in their bones. They wield their implements like knives, cutting meaning from the void. Some cut deeper than others. Fitzgerald knew this and in The Great Gatsby he carved his meanings with precision, though perhaps he did not know the fullness of what he wrought. He would take words that had no business laying together and force them into an unholy union, creating something new and terrible and beautiful. But it was in color that he found his truest voice, like an old testament prophet speaking in tongues of gold and green and white and red, though the meaning lay deeper than mere pigment or light.

The white and the gray spoke of sameness, of the crushing weight of uniformity that lay across the land like a burial shroud. White belonged to the moneyed folk, pristine and untouched, while gray was what remained when time had done its work. They wore their whites like armor - Daisy and Jordan moving through rooms like pale ghosts, Nick in his white flannels at Gatsby's bacchanal, Tom's white shirt when he met his woman in the city. All of them wrapped in white like corpses prepared for burial. Only at Gatsby's revelries did the white give way, replaced by vulgar primary colors that screamed their defiance into the night.

The white crept into everything, staining the world like bleach. The canyons of New York stood white and terrible, the names of party guests faded to gray specters on Nick's papers, apartment buildings lined up like pale tombstones reaching toward a godless sky. The people too wore their colors like brands - Jordan and Daisy's white childhood marking them as surely as a rancher's iron, while in the valley of ashes gray cars crept through gray land like mechanical phantoms. Even the Italian child bore the mark of gray, and the old man selling dogs was gray as winter twilight.

When Fitzgerald had loaded these colors with enough meaning they became weapons in his arsenal. Daisy appears again in white, in her white car, and we see her then for what she truly is - not a woman of flesh and blood but a uniform thing, a prize to be won, an object of Gatsby's desperate yearning. Her fur collar carries the gray like a prophecy, and when she appears again in white before the final confrontation it is both declaration and judgment, uniform and sentence all at once.

The county lay spread before them like some fevered dream of plenty, the sun-bleached hills giving way to ordered rows of fruit and vine. They rode past fields of tomatoes blood-red in the morning light and citrus groves hanging heavy with bitter fruit. The land was good here. Always had been. Even now in these modern times the earth yielded its bounty to those who would work it, organic they called it now, though it was nothing more than the old ways come back around again.

They passed a farm where people gathered, city folk with their clean shoes and pressed clothes waiting in lines that stretched beyond counting just to claim their share of what the earth provided. Eggs and milk and honey. The old man spat in the dust. Said there was money in showing folks around too, letting them walk the paths between the crops like it was some kind of spectacle and not just the way things had always been done.

The piece they were looking at butted up against Cleveland Forest, one hundred and sixty acres of scrub and oak and grassland that wasnt native but had taken hold anyway like so many things in this country. The land had history. Indians had lived there longer than anyone could reckon, then the cattlemen came with their herds and the woodcutters with their axes and now here they were, talking about kangaroo rats and yellow-legged frogs like they were gold. Government men had lists of creatures they said needed saving, butterflies and birds with names like gnatcatcher, though who had ever caught gnats was another question entirely.

The old man said it would take more work than the regular way of farming, fighting the weeds and the bugs without poison, watching the crops die sometimes when there wasnt nothing you could do about it. But there was help to be had if you knew where to look, money from men in offices who'd never worked the land themselves but who'd decided how it ought to be worked all the same. The old man knew a place nearby that was making it work, organic they called it, though it was just farming the way his grandaddy would have known it. Said maybe that was the future, though it looked an awful lot like the past.

There's a thing between brothers that ain't natural and ain't made by man. It's older than blood and deeper than bone. It carries love and pride and mean things too, things that have no name but live in the dark spaces between heartbeats. Brothers know each other like they know their own face in still water, seeing themselves in the other's eyes like some terrible mirror that shows truth instead of reflection.

When the world turns wrong and everything goes black as pitch, that's when you see what kind of bond holds. Good or evil, it don't matter. It just is. And whatever comes of it carries a price that must be paid in full. No credit given, no promises accepted. Just cold payment in whatever coin the world demands.

In the story they call The Scarlet Ibis there's these two brothers walking through a world green and wet and full of things dying. The older one, he's got pride eating at him like rust on iron, and the younger one, Doodle, he's born wrong, fragile as a bird's bones. They set out on a fool's errand through swamps where old women's ghosts still walk, and only one comes back breathing.

The older brother, he wanted what couldn't be had. Wanted to teach running and climbing and all manner of things to a boy whose heart was weak as water. Wanted someone to race through the pinewoods to Horsehead Landing, wanted someone to sit high in the trees where the wind lives. But you can't make a racing horse from a broken-legged colt, and he knew it. The knowing ate at him worse than the wanting.

There was a time he looked at that baby brother and thought about sending him to Jesus with a pillow. Thought about it like a man thinks about killing a wounded animal. But the baby smiled and something in that smile reached down into whatever dark place that killing thought came from and pulled out something like love instead. Even if he didn't know it was love at the time. Even if he wouldn't know it until it was too late.

The mind of man is a dark and twisted thing, a labyrinth of flesh and electricity that moves like God's own clockwork through the skull. In the old days they said it was like wax that could be marked upon, then paper, then books bound in leather, and now they speak of machines that think in ones and zeros, but all these things are just shadows on a wall, poor reflections of the truth that lies beneath.

The world comes in through gates of flesh. Light and sound and heat, all of them transformed into something else, something that runs like lightning through the corridors of the brain. They called it processing, as if the mind was some kind of slaughterhouse for reality. The signals move up and down like spirits in a house, bottom to top and top to bottom. Take a black box sitting on white. The eye sees edges first, boundaries where darkness meets light, and the mind builds it up piece by piece like a carpenter working in reverse. Then from above comes knowledge, memory, expectation. The box becomes more than shapes. It becomes real.

There's a guardian in there too, watching, deciding what matters and what don't. You might be standing in grass up to your ankles but your mind won't count each blade unless it has to. But hear your name spoke across a crowded room and something in you turns like a wolf hearing prey in the distance.

The mind keeps its treasures like a crow keeps bright things, storing them away in different nests. Some memories last only moments, like smoke in the wind. Others stick around for maybe twenty seconds, running in circles like a dog chasing its tail through the neural paths. And some, the ones that really matter, they get carved into the very meat of you, written in proteins like scripture in stone.

They tried to map it all out, these men of science with their theories and their models. They drew pictures of it like a web, with every thought connected to every other thought by strings of meaning. Chair to table, table to wood, wood to tree, tree to forest, forest to darkness. All of it linked together in a great network that stretches through the skull like stars in the night sky, each one burning with its own fierce light.

They called it the great unraveling. In the year of our Lord 2007 the markets fell and with them fell the dreams and hopes and futures of countless souls who had staked their claims on promises writ in sand. The unemployment came like a thief in the night and the houses stood empty like the skulls of dead things in the desert and the great corporations that had stood like giants astride the nation lay broken and bleeding in the dust.

The seeds of this darkness were planted in older times. In the Clinton years when men dreamed of power eternal and sought to buy the hearts of the masses with promises of homes they could not afford. They rewrote the ancient laws of lending like false prophets rewriting scripture and the banks genuflected before the altar of profit and risk. Fannie Mae and its twisted sister Freddie Mac packaged these poisoned promises and sold them like snakeoil across the land.

The mortgages were crafted by men who dealt in shadows and complexity. They fashioned instruments of debt more byzantine than the labyrinths of old, weaving together the fates of millions in webs of paper and promise. CDOs they called them, and CMOs, and a hundred other names in a tongue that spoke only of greed. The people leveraged their futures against dreams and the dreams turned to nightmares when the bubble burst like a boil upon the face of the nation.

When the reckoning came it came with the swift terrible justice of an Old Testament God. The great houses of finance tottered and fell. Bear Stearns. Merrill Lynch. Lehman Brothers. Their names now whispered like the names of dead kings. Four trillion in debt hung like a millstone around their necks. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley survived but were transformed, made to wear the chains of regulation like penitents. Fannie and Freddie, those twin towers of hubris, fell into the arms of the government like prodigal children seeking sanctuary. September 2008. The month when the old world died and the new world was born in blood and bankruptcy.

The words lay there like bones bleached white in desert sun. Exposition. A word that carries weight like a coffin carried by pallbearers who dont know the dead. Writers take to it like vultures to carrion, thinking their prose will sing but finding instead it croaks deep in the throat of the reader who holds no patience for such things.

The old doctor would curse at the screen when she found herself trapped in passages thick with detail that served no purpose save to fill space with words. Words that carried no blood in them. No life. Just dead things arranged in rows like headstones in an abandoned graveyard.

Show dont tell. The writers commandment carved in stone but broken daily like any other holy decree. The devil that whispers to put down the history first sits on one shoulder while its twin perches on the other urging every detail of every life be spelled out in full. Neither devil speaks truth.

To tell a thing is to kill it. When a man speaks to camera explaining how things came to be its already too late. The story has died in his mouth before the words take flight. In books the writer becomes that man, that teller of dead tales.

Consider the woman who lost her man. You could say they met and married and he died. Three things that happened like three bullets fired into the night. But that aint the truth of it. The truth lives in how his hands moved when he spoke to her that first time. How the rain fell the day they wed. How his blood looked black as oil in the moonlight when they put him down. These things carry the weight of truth. The rest is just wind passing through empty rooms.

A writer must give meat to these bones but most times they rush past like coyotes with fresh kill, dropping pieces of the truth as they run. They got a man who worked nights at a gas station, former Air Force, twice married and childless, who likes to fish and dreams of owning that station someday. They think knowing he ate eggs benedict that morning matters. It dont. What matters is how he holds his coffee cup like it might break. How he stares out into the dark thinking about things that cant be changed. That's where the story lives.

The morning brought news like carrion birds circling. First came word from Ashley, a town small and godless, where a man named Hostettler had put knife to wife. His face in the jailhouse photo bore the hollow eyes of something ancient and terrible. The story passed quick as summer lightning, leaving only the echo of steel meeting flesh.

Then came word of the boy Buyers, eighteen summers old, shot down in Sharon Woods. The streets there run dark with old sins, and the SWAT men moved through them like black-clad pilgrims seeking redemption that wouldn't come. The news gave it scarce attention, like they always did when dark skin met darker fate. White flesh makes better stories, they reckon, though death makes no such distinction.

A bullet had found the Med-Flight bird, a .22 singing through metal skin. Five thousand dollars to name the shooter, though money rarely loosens true tongues. The weather woman spoke of rain coming, her words a incantation against the heat that held the city in its grip. Mid-eighties, she said, like numbers could capture the weight of August air.

They told of a UDF store on Clime Road, robbed by a man they described like reading scripture - dark-skinned, hooded, tall and lean as a desert coyote. They lingered on his blackness like preachers on sin. Then came the tale of Rodriguez, the Texas man who'd sent green poison north. Three hundred months they gave him, not twenty-five years, as if breaking time into smaller pieces might make the sentence weigh more heavy. They named him Hispanic, though the drugs he moved cared nothing for the blood of those who carried them.

All these stories floating like ash in morning light, each one carrying its own kind of darkness, its own particular damnation.

They call it an ETF and it moves like a shadow across the financial plains, tracking indices and commodities and baskets of assets like some dark harbinger of wealth. It trades like any stock would trade but carries within it multitudes, like some great beast containing smaller beasts, all of them moving in concert across the electronic wilderness of the exchange.

The thing about an ETF is it gives a man what he needs. Diversification. The ability to sell short when the darkness comes. Margin buying when opportunity presents itself. A man can buy one share or a thousand and the transaction cares not which. The costs they keep low, lower than them mutual funds that promise the same things but deliver less. But there aint nothing in this world comes without its price and the commissions you pay like death taking its due.

The variety of these funds stretches far as the eye can see but a man must look careful at what they promise. Diversification they say. Benefits they claim. But the wise know that promises need testing against the hard light of day.

We set our eyes on one called IHF, studying it like a tracker would study spoor in the desert sand. Comparing it against its ten largest holdings like comparing a wolf to the pack that made it. We aimed to know if owning the one was better than owning the ten separate, and if there might be some better way to arrange these pieces into something that would yield more bounty.

The task of examining every holding would be like counting every grain of sand in the Mojave so we took the top ten, accounting for 63.58 percent of what the thing held within its borders. These ten we listed out with their percentages like counting coup.

To know how these ten represented the whole we did the calculations, cold and merciless as winter arithmetic. We normalized them to hundred percent, figured their contribution to Beta and Return like some financial alchemist seeking truth in numbers. The results we laid out in charts black and stark as cemetery markers.

What the numbers told was this: them ten holdings alone would yield 6.11 percent more than the ETF itself, like finding extra water in what you thought was a dry well. The Beta ran lower too, by point twelve. But numbers can lie like any man can lie and we needed to know if these differences were real as blood or just shadows cast by statistical moonlight.

The numbers told a story and it wasnt a good one. They fell like dead leaves in that third month, scattered and forgotten on the cold New England ground. Winter had come as it always did, merciless and raw, and the bicycles stood abandoned like metal skeletons against the brick walls. The footprints in the snow grew fewer. The people who once walked now drove their machines, sealed against the wind and ice like pilgrims in iron churches.

December brought its own peculiar madness. The scholars bent over their books and the teachers over their marks and the logging of journeys became a thing of ghosts and memories. Then the holidays came and the campus emptied like a dead town in some forsaken territory, wind whistling through the empty corridors where once there were footsteps.

They came back in January but the numbers stayed low, a fact that could not be explained away by the cold or the snow or the dark mornings that made men seek the comfort of their automobiles. February was worse still. Perhaps it was the nature of such things that the fire burns bright at first then dims to coals and ash. We tried to rekindle it with what we called the Carpool Challenge Week in March, a desperate flaring that brought some warmth back to the numbers.

The truth was simpler and harder both. The machine had become like a second skin to these people, a carapace of steel and glass that spoke to something deeper than convenience. It was freedom itself, hammered into shape in Detroit and Tokyo, freedom that had seeped into the blood and bones of a nation. We fought it with trinkets - paper promises for coffee and books and food. But perhaps we should have fought steel with steel, tempted them with better machines - bicycles wrought fine as spiderwebs, automobiles that ran on lightning instead of dead dinosaurs. Maybe then the numbers would have told a different story. Maybe then the parking lots wouldn't have swallowed up the earth like tar pits, waiting to fossilize our good intentions.

They were fifteen of them. Edison's trick films. Made in them years between 1895 and 1901 and stored now in that great repository of memory called the Library of Congress. Films that dealt in illusions and deceptions, wrought from the manipulation of the captured light itself. Most followed a strict catechism of rules, like ancient rites passed down through generations of showmen, though some dared venture beyond these bounds.

The films lived within wooden boxes, confined like prisoners to their proscenium frames. No movement of the eye that captured them, just the stark geometry of the stage inherited from those tattered vaudeville halls where magicians once plied their trade. The figures moved like specters across the frame, east to west, never daring to approach the glass eye that watched them. In one such phantom play called Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel, made in that last year before the century turned, the players moved like clockwork figures on their horizontal rails, disappearing into the void beyond the frame's edge while the camera stood witness, immobile as stone.

These were pictures made at distance. No intimate portraits here. The camera kept its respectful remove like a mourner at a funeral, showing all and revealing nothing. Close-up shots were forbidden fruit in these early days, when the medium still wore its theatrical chains. The players kept to their appointed grounds, neither advancing nor retreating, trapped in that middle distance like souls in purgatory.

Time itself was compressed in these reels. One shot, one film, that was the law. A minute or less of light and shadow, captured at varying speeds as if time itself was uncertain. They were simple things, these tricks. Disappearances, transformations, the stuff of carnival shows. But look closer at The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots, that grim spectacle from 1895. Watch how the illusion fractures if you study it hard enough, the moment when Mary's head becomes no more than a prop, though the eye wants to see it whole. That's the true trick of it. Not in the making but in the believing.

In the dark hollows of literary history there lies what men call the Gothic Novel, a thing both ancient and new, like some terrible creature born of time itself. Ian Watt spoke of it as an oxymoron, this old-new thing, but words are wind and definitions are the chains men forge to bind what cannot be bound. The Gothic rides through our consciousness like a midnight rider, praised and damned in equal measure, called shallow by some and sublime by others who spoke of terror like Burke did, as if terror could be contained in words alone.

It began with Walpole and his Castle of Otranto, that first dark seed planted in the garden of letters. He took the ancient ways and the modern paths and wed them together like some unholy union, birthing what he named A Gothic Story. The gothic ways ran deep in it like roots in black earth - medieval theatre, stone arches pointing to heaven, traditions old as blood. Even then gothic meant many things to many men, like a word that had lost its way in time, wandering through centuries marked primitive by those who called themselves modern and enlightened.

But it was the marriage of these things - the theatrical gothic with its masks and its mysteries, and the novel with its way of peeling back the skull to see the thoughts beneath - that gave it life eternal. It became like some ageless thing, dead but not dying, new but not young, speaking across the vast desert of years to readers yet unborn.

The ghost of Chivalry haunts these pages like a revenant that will not rest. In Otranto it lives and breathes, though changed from what it was in medieval times when knights rode forth in steel and honor. Walpole saw his world bereft of such things, saw politics and power strip bare the bones of honor until nothing remained but hollow men in hollow halls. He yearned for what was lost, for the idealized past that perhaps never was, but in that yearning he created something new.

In his character of Frederic we see this clearest, like looking through dark water to stones beneath. Before he steps onto the stage we know him by the marks of chivalry upon his soul - a prince who has known suffering, who has walked through fire and shadow, believed dead at the hands of infidels in some far land. Here stands the knight of old tales, but twisted, exaggerated, excessive like all things gothic must be, as if viewed through a glass that magnifies and distorts until the familiar becomes strange and the strange becomes familiar.

They called it supply chain management and it was a thing born of necessity in the minds of men who sought to move goods across vast spaces from maker to buyer through the raw materials and the making and the moving and all manner of commerce between. A consultant named Oliver had given it this name in 1982 though the thing itself was ancient as trade itself. It was a process both simple and complex in its execution, like the weaving of a vast tapestry where each thread must find its place lest the whole thing come undone.

Six elements existed in this chain and they were like the bones of some great beast: production and supply and inventory and location and transportation and information. Each one vital as blood, each one carrying its own weight in the grand scheme of things.

Production stood first among these elements, a foundation stone upon which all else was built. In the way of all things it began with want, with need, with desire. The managers would study the market like seers reading entrails, trying to divine what the people would buy and what they would not. They would make their decisions based on these auguries, choosing what would be made and where it would be made and how many would be made. Each decision carried weight, each choice echoing down through the chain like thunder across empty plains.

He had seen this himself in the great retail houses of Walmart and Target, where every action was prescribed and every movement calculated, down to the very clothes the workers wore and the way the trucks were emptied of their goods. It was a machinery vast and precise, and like all machinery it could fail if not tended proper.

Then there was supply, that great decision of what would be done within the walls and what would be sent to others to do. They called it outsourcing when they sent the work away, seeking that thing they called velocity, though velocity was nothing more than the marriage of quality and flexibility with the eternal pursuit of lower costs. It was a dance of numbers and capabilities, of core competencies and strategic partnerships, all of it moving in a rhythm old as commerce itself.

They came in the dark Victorian age like wraiths or phantoms stalking the halls of literature. Books of the aristocracy and their ways. Books of parlors and teacups and proper manners laid bare upon the page in infinite detail as if God himself had ordained their cataloguing. But there were others. Different ones. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights stood apart from their kin like dark sheep in a pristine flock, carrying with them elements of mystery and the bizarre that no proper Victorian novel would dare embrace. These elements moved through the stories like smoke, seeping into the characters, making them more real somehow. More true.

"And now hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind." That's what they wrote of Oliver. He walked between Sikes and Crackit who were not there but were there all the same, their voices real as gunsmoke in his ears. The boy stumbled through this fever dream while shots rang out and lights blazed across his vision like St. Elmo's fire and all the while pain rode him like a demon, constant and merciless.

These fever dreams and nightmares served as windows into souls. In Oliver's case they laid bare the helplessness of a child cast adrift in a world of wolves. When the shooting came back to him in the twenty-eighth chapter it came like a visitation, like judgment. He was there again. The pistol. The flash. The darkness. Some unseen hand bearing him away while Sikes and Crackit argued in his head like specters at a hanging. The pain was everywhere and nowhere. It had become like breathing. Like existing. The boy was powerless in this world of men and monsters, his will counted for nothing, and old Fagin's poison had already begun to work its way into his blood, into his bones, into whatever remained of hope.

The day that wasnt a day passed and night came again. Long night. Short night. Silent as death and gone in an instant.

In them days I worked with the children after their schooling was done, them small faces bent over books and papers in the failing light. English and reading was what I knew best and that's what I done. There was this boy named Adrian, might've been nine or ten years old, struggling with his letters like a blind man counting coins. Something wasnt right with how he read. Some letters he knew true as sunrise but others might as well been hieroglyphs carved in stone by ancient peoples long dead.

The boy was Mexican sure enough but spoke English pure as any native born. We went on like that for a time until his mother come in one afternoon while the others was gone on some expedition. She stood there in her clean work clothes speaking no English at all, just Spanish words falling soft like rain. My own Spanish was poor but we managed somehow. That's when it hit me like a hammer blow. The boy could read right enough but the English letters was foreign to him, like tracks in the desert that dont match no animal you know.

I tell this tale not just to speak on the wall between languages in our schools out here in California but to show how the obvious aint always obvious at all. Even a child speaking perfect English might find reading it like crossing a river in flood. We all know this truth but what's to be done about it? For Adrian it was simple enough - teach him them letters and sounds till they was familiar as his own face in the mirror. But for them children who barely speak English at all, that's a harder path to walk.

Ain't no single answer neither. Two-language teaching, throwing them in with English speakers, private teaching, special classes - none of these alone is gonna fix what's broke. The answer lies in using all of them together like a man needs both horse and saddle to ride. The two-language way of teaching is good for all children, not just them that speak Spanish first. Studies show these children do better than their peers but folk still fear it like they fear what they dont understand. If we was to make this the rule instead of the exception, every child would profit from it. We dont need every teacher speaking two languages - that aint realistic. But we sure could use some special helpers who know both tongues, like scouts who know both sides of the border.

From the time we are young they tell us there is something greater than ourselves out there in the vast dark. Something beyond knowing. The old ones send their young to houses of God built of wood and stone and glass where they learn tales passed down through time immemorial. Some take these stories into themselves like bread and water while others cast them away, declaring themselves alone in the void. We wander through our days seeking meaning in different vessels, different shapes, trading one truth for another like worn currency. All of us searching for that pale fire in the blackness that might lead us home.

The old man said cardinal and nothing more. We set in the failing light watching the rain beat against the tin roof, smoke rising from our cigarettes like lost prayers. Water ran in the gutters and drowned the flowers that mother had planted years ago. He looked out into the gray waste of evening with eyes that seemed to see both nothing and everything at once. His clothes hung on him like a scarecrow's rags, his skull showing through the thinning hair like something unearthed. We didnt speak. What words could fill such spaces. I moved closer and we watched the rain together while the day bled out into darkness.

He died in the winter. Five days after I turned twenty-two. The doctors had given him poison to fight the poison in his blood but it only stretched his suffering like a wire drawn too tight. I cursed God in the nighttime. Sat in rooms darker than any church and spoke no prayers to the emptiness. If there was something out there listening it had turned its face from us long ago.

I did not watch him die. Could not. The witnessing of such things marks a soul in ways that cant be unnamed. I wanted him alive in my memory not cold and white in some sterile room where machines counted down his last hours. They knew, all of them, that his only son would not stand vigil at his passing. I lay in my bed for three days like Jonah in the belly of the whale waiting for word.

None came.

He was a man of the soil first and of politics second, this John Taylor of Caroline, and in him burned something fierce and righteous about the nature of freedom and the proper role of governance. The earth itself had shaped his thoughts on what a nation ought be, and from this came all else: his views on sovereignty and law and justice and the machinery of state.

The land was new then. Virgin territory for governance unmarred by the old ways that had poisoned the minds of men across the water. Taylor saw in this emptiness a terrible possibility. He knew that rights given by God or nature or whatever force breathed life into mankind were like links in an iron chain, break one and the whole thing falls to rust and ruin. These things, he reckoned, must stay beyond the reach of men who would rule other men.

Some spoke of natural states where the strong and cunning preyed upon the weak, but Taylor knew civilization must rise above such base things. He carried within him a stark vision of good and evil, like day and night with no twilight between. The government, he said, must account for both these forces dwelling in the hearts of men. Good was the protection of property and the cultivation of soil. Evil was the gathering of wealth through paper and promises. He knew that self-interest drove all men but saw how it could twist and corrupt, creating parasites who fed upon the labor of others.

The Constitution, he believed, must be read like scripture - strict but with wisdom. Let the federal government be small and bound by chains of paper and ink, for a fat government grows hungry and tyrannical. But words alone were not enough. The spirit of the law must be understood, the intentions of those who wrote it known. And above all else stood the Declaration, that first document which spoke of sovereign states joined in common cause but not merged into one great beast of governance.

He would have seen what was coming, this Caroline farmer. Would have watched the slow death of his agrarian dream with eyes that knew too well the darkness that dwelled in men's hearts when power called to them. But he planted his ideas like seeds in the furrows of a young nation's mind, and some took root and grow there still.

He stood there and looked down and the looking was a thing without emotion or connection to the world of men. His mind moved like water over stones, thoughts coming and going unbidden and unbound by the constraints of consciousness until there was nothing left but the pure act of seeing.

He'd bought the book once. An art book. Some woman who wrote about the brain and how to make it draw what the eye sees true. She wrote of frames and squares and how to parse the world into pieces small enough for a man to understand. How to take the vast terrible everything of existence and cut it down to size. But there was no frame now. No square. Just the terrible brown truth of what lay before him.

The porcelain was white as bone. White as the skulls of dead things in the desert. He touched the silver handle with fingers that knew their purpose and watched the water spiral down like some primal force of nature. The brown mass stayed. Unmoved. Uncaring. Like something ancient buried in the earth that refused to yield its secrets.

He stood in his uniform. The green tie at his throat like a noose. The mop beside him like a companion in this strange ritual. The fluorescent lights of the Rite Aid bathroom cast no shadows and in their stark truth there was nowhere to hide from what must be done. He pulled at the paper on the wall, wrapping his hand like a man preparing for war, layer upon layer until the shape of his hand was lost in the whiteness. Then he reached down into the water the way a man reaches into his own past knowing there is no good thing to find there.

The water was cold. Cold as death. Cold as truth.

They die on the roads these children. Die in twisted metal and shattered glass while the night wraps around them like a shroud. The government men in their clean white coats say the young mind aint ready for such things. That it cannot grasp the weight of steel and speed and death that comes with it. But they drive all the same.

The inexperience sits in them like poison. Makes them roll vehicles that ought not roll. Makes them press pedals that ought not be pressed. Makes them leave roads that ought to be followed. And they travel in packs these young ones. Like wolves but without the wisdom that wolves carry in their blood. Some state men in California watched them die and counted the bodies and made charts of the dead showing how they died more when they ran together.

The state tried to fix it. Made papers that said when they could drive and who could ride with them. But papers dont stop blood from flowing when metal meets metal on the midnight highways. Papers dont make young minds old.

Some doctor named Zuckerman he says even eighteen years aint enough. Says the young ones seek the thrill of it like addicts seeking poison. Says we ought to wait till the blood runs cooler in their veins. But we dont wait and they keep dying and soon there will be more of them. Children of the boomers coming up like dark clouds on the horizon ready to take their turn at the wheel.

Could make a law about it. Simple thing really. Keep them learning in schools but keep them off the roads till eighteen years have passed. Make them prove themselves like California does with their fifty hours of watching and learning. Make it the same everywhere across this blood-soaked nation.

Aint nothing new in what I say. Just truth that sits there plain as death on a highway.

They call it Central Auditory Processing Disorder and it lives in the spaces between hearing and knowing. Not in the ear itself but in the dark corridors of the brain where sound becomes meaning. Like a demon that steals understanding from the minds of those afflicted leaving them whole in body but fractured in comprehension.

The disorder moves through three territories and we will walk them all. First the nature of the thing itself. Then the marking of its presence in the afflicted, the signs writ in behavior and confusion that herald its existence. Last the methods by which those who teach might aid the cursed ones in rooms full of the blessed.

It began in the middle years of the last century. Italian men with names like Bocca and Calearo hunting for understanding in the minds of children who could hear but could not listen. They created tests. Mapped the territories of confusion. In 1977 they gathered, these searchers of broken sound, to share their dark knowledge.

The disorder manifests like a ghost in the machine of consciousness. Some cannot locate sound in space as if the world were flat and dimensionless. Some cannot parse the difference between sounds that fall like rain upon their ears. Some cannot hear the mockery in a voice or the anger beneath soft words. The sounds come but meaning dies stillborn in the mind.

They test for it now with machines and questionnaires and observations recorded in careful hands. Audiologists and speech pathologists move through the darkness of the affliction with their instruments like blind men with sticks, tapping at the walls of comprehension. They send sounds into the ear like scouts into enemy territory and measure what returns. But no single test can capture its presence fully. The disorder remains elusive, like smoke in a closed room, its origins unknown, its territory mapped but never fully conquered.

They were the lost ones. The broken ones. Children with eyes like empty wells and families splintered like old wood left too long in the sun. I knew them before I knew their names. Knew their stories written in bruises and silence. The social work, it called to me like a dark bell tolling in the night.

Service and respect aint just words writ on paper. They're carved deep in the bone. In the marrow. Ethics aint something you learn from books neither. You carry it or you dont.

I wandered them halls of learning for years, watching them young ones flee from their demons. Some found poison in the bottle, others in the needle. After Piedmont College in 09 I drifted like smoke until that summer day when fate showed its hand. There was this boy. Sixteen maybe. Sitting scared on my friend's couch like a sparrow in a thunderstorm. His parents had done things. Bad things. Dark things that leave scars deeper than skin.

I went to their house. The law was there already, blue lights cutting through the twilight like cold stars. Told them what I knew. What I'd learned in them psychology books. They asked me to talk to the parents and I did. Heard their excuses like bitter wind through dead trees. Simple disputes, they called it. Simple. Nothing simple about terror in a child's eyes.

Justice. That's what they say we got but it aint true. Society wants its people to follow like sheep. Wants em numbered and counted and sorted. But I seen different. Seen the truth of it. In school I fought against their rules like a wolf fights against the trap. Colored my hair wild colors that nature never dreamed of. Marked my flesh with metal. Stood with them that society said weren't worth standing with. Gay. Straight. Bisexual. All God's creatures carrying their own truth.

Racism and hate, they're like poison in the well. Been fighting against em since I could stand. Still am. Always will be. That's the path I chosen. Or maybe it chosen me. Either way, here I am, walking toward them dark places where children cry in the night, carrying whatever light I got left to give.

Sleep comes unbidden like a thief in the night or it doesnt come at all. The disorder they call insomnia stands before us like some dark totem carved from the bones of sleepless nights, its shadow cast long across the biological and sociocultural planes of human understanding. They who study such things speak of models and methods, of inherited traits passed down through blood and bone, and of the world that shapes us like wind shapes stone.

The categorization of sleep's absence comes in three forms, each more merciless than the last. Primary disorders stand alone like sentinels in the night. Others walk hand in hand with the demons of the mind, those axis disorders that plague mankind since time immemorial. And still others come from the poison we put in our bodies or the failing of our mortal shells.

In the realm of primary disorders there are the Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, names given by men in white coats to the horrors that stalk the night. Insomnia, that cruel mistress, denies sleep to those who seek it. Hypersomnia, her sister, drags men down into unwanted slumber like stones beneath dark water. Narcolepsy strikes like a serpent, sudden and without mercy. The Parasomnias bring their own terrors - nightmares that tear through the mind like wolves through flesh, sleep terrors that freeze the blood, and sleepwalking that sends the unconscious body wandering through the dark hours.

Deep in the hypothalamus, in the microscopic spaces between life and death, neurons fire like distant stars. They carry orexin, the messenger of wake and sleep, through channels as old as time itself. The scientists, they found these things in mice first. GABAB receptors, they called them, gatekeepers of consciousness. When they opened these gates with their chemicals and medicines, sleep came like a flood. But nature is cruel and what works in mice may not work in men. The inheritance of such mechanisms through bloodlines means some are born to wander the night while others sleep sound in their beds.

Been here two and a half years now. Four and a half semesters in this place they call University Park where the wind howls cold across empty spaces between buildings and the snow falls sideways like God's own spite. Started out in East Halls, far as you could go before hitting wilderness and stadium concrete. Stuart Hall was home then. Twenty-five minutes walking to Willard through weather that'd freeze the heart of hell itself. That's how it goes in State College.

Talked once to someone who'd been here before. Not much older but spoke of different times. Said East Halls stood alone then, separated by vast emptiness like some forsaken outpost. Now sports fields and buildings rise up from that emptiness. New Creamery. New health building. Apartments sprout like weeds in cracked earth. Campus grows like some living thing, stretching, expanding, making distance longer with each passing season.

The bicycle. That's what saves you here. Simple machine of steel and rubber but it needs more than just existing. Needs riders. Needs paths. Needs purpose.

Friend of mine found his way back to cycling after years away from it. Said he couldn't reckon why he'd ever stopped. Nothing else like it for getting around, he said, fashion be damned. Bowl of oatmeal becomes thirty miles of freedom. Living off campus now myself, far as any dorm ever was. Bought a bike. Best thing I done. Thomas building sits twenty-five minutes walking distance from where I sleep. On the bike, five minutes if you're willing to push. Pollock Road runs straight as an arrow but it ain't friendly. Not to bikes. Not to nothing really.

Walking's got its merits sure enough but time ain't one of them. Thirty minutes extra each way to Thomas. Two and a half hours gone each week like smoke in wind. More when you count everything else needs doing. Time's a currency can't be borrowed back once spent. Bike saves what little I got left of it.

They had come to see what the old man Huxley had writ about the machines and the money and how they worked together like serpents in the dark. In his book about the brave world that was to come he showed them people who lived not as ones but as many, folks who sought nothing but the quick pleasure of the moment like animals rutting in the field. And above them all stood the Controller like some dark god, moving his pieces across a board none could see.

The dead prophets of old had spoke of such things. Marx and his ilk who saw how the powerful made the weak believe lies about their own chains. In this new world they had built the people were less than cattle, branded and sorted by letters like freight in a trainyard. Deltas. Gammas. Names that meant nothing and everything. They filled their heads with whispered commands while they slept, telling them to spend and want and need until there wasnt nothing left inside them that was their own.

Weren't no real love in this place neither. The people moved through their days like ghosts, touching but never feeling, speaking but never saying. The men talked of women like they was discussing livestock, measuring their worth in flesh and curves they called pneumatic. The women were no better, trading stories of their rutting like they was discussing the weather. Each class of folk stayed in their place like it was writ in stone, believing the lies they'd been fed since before they could walk. They consumed and obeyed and never looked up to see the bars of their cage, thinking themselves free while wearing chains they'd been taught to love.

The Controller watched it all from his high tower, knowing what Marx knew - that if you tell a man he's special while you rob him blind, he'll thank you for the privilege. And so they went on, all of them, dancing to music they couldn't hear, played by hands they couldn't see.

Four years past I sat in a room where they spoke of Islam. The question hung in the air like woodsmoke, heavy and acrid. Whether this faith carried violence in its bones. The years since the towers fell have shifted like desert sands, the wind of public opinion blowing first one way then another, media voices crying hostility then tolerance in equal measure. Now we stand in a time where a man called Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his lineage, could reach for the highest seat in the land. Such things were not dreamt of in the days when the towers still stood.

The Prophet's tale troubles me. It moves against what history whispers, like two streams flowing contrary. I had known Muhammad as a conqueror, a man who bent tribes to his will and branded their souls with his faith through steel and fire.
